Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Banik, Naren L.
BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH
Give the following information for the key personnel and consultants and collaborators. Begin with the principal investigator/program director. Photocopy this page for each person.
NAME
Hogan, Edward. L., M.D.
POSITION TITLE Professor and Chairman/Neurology
EDUCATION (Begin with baccalaureate or other initial professional education, such as nursing, and include postdoctoral training.)
INSTITUTION AND LOCATION
DEGREE
YEAR CONFERRED
FIELD OF STUDY
Tufts University, Medford, MA
B.S.
1953
Biochemistry
Tufts University School of Medicine, Boston, MA
M.D.
1957
Medicine
RESEARCH AND PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE: Concluding with present position, list, in chronological order, previous employment, experience, and honors. Key personnel include the principal investigator and any other individuals who participate in the scientific development or execution of the project. Key personnel typically will include all individuals with doctoral or other professional degrees, but in some projects will include individuals at the masters or baccalaureate level provided they contribute in a substantive way to the scientific development or execution of the project. Include present membership on any Federal Government public advisory committee. List, in chronological order, the titles, all authors, and complete references to all publications during the past three years and to representative earlier publications pertinent to this application. DO NOT EXCEED TWO PAGES.
Intern, Ward Medical Service, Barnes Hospital, St. Louis, MO, 1957-58 Assistant Resident/Medicine, Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston, MA, 1958-59 Resident/Neurology, Neurology Unit, Boston City Hospital, Boston, MA, 1959-61 Active Duty, United States Army, Fort Dix, NJ, 1961-63
Postdoctoral Fellow/Neuropathology, Harvard University, Boston, MA, 1963-64 Postdoctoral Fellow/Biochemistry, Tufts University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, 1964-66
Assistant and Associate Professor/Medicine (Neurology), University of North Carolina School of Medicine, Chapel Hill, NC, 1966-73
Assistant and Associate Professor/Biochemistry, University of North Carolina School of Medicine, Chapel Hill, NC, 1966-73
Professor and Chairman, Department of Neurology, Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, 1973-Present
Professor/Biochemistry, Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, 1973-Present
AWARDS, COMMITTEES: Merit Review Board in Neurobiology, Veterans Administra- tion, 1976-79; Neurology B Study Section, National Institutes of Health, 1981-85; Neuroscience Training Committee, National Institutes of Health, 1989-93
SELECTED PUBLICATIONS: (From more than 300 papers and abstracts)
1. Banik NL, Powers JM, Hogan EL: The effects of spinal cord trauma on myelin. J Neuropath Exp Neurol 39:232-244, 1980.
2. Happel RD, Smith KP, Banik NL, Powers JM, Hogan EL, Balentine JD: Calcium accumulation in experimental spinal cord trauma, Brain Res 211:476-479, 1981.
3. Banik NL, McAlhaney WW, Hogan EL: Calcium-stimulated proteolysis in myelin: Evidence of a Ca2+-activated neutral proteinase associated with purified myelin of rat CNS. J Neurochem 45:581-588, 1985.
4. Hsu CY, Halushka PV, Hogan EL, Banik NL, Lee WA, Perot PL: Alteration of thromboxane and prostacyclin levels in experimental spinal cord injury. Neurology 35:1003-1009, 1985.
5. Hsu CY, Hogan EL, Gadsden RH, Spicer KM, Shi MP, Cox R: Post-traumatic calcium accumulation as a function of increased vascular permeability in experimental spinal cord injury. J Neurol Sci 70:275-282, 1985.
PHS 398 (Rev. 9/91) (Form Page 6) Page 15 Number pages consecutively at the bottom throughout the application. Do not use suffixes such as 3a. 3b. FF
